conclusion: Understand what a velocity-time graph tells me.
In a velocity-time graph, the x-axis is time in seconds (s), and the y-axis is velocity in meters per second (m/s).
The positive direction is usually upwards, and negative direction is downwards.
Time goes from 0 to 3 seconds, and velocity ranges from -2 m/s to +2 m/s.
From t=0 to t=1 second, the velocity is constant at +2 m/s.
At t=1 second, the velocity starts to decrease linearly.
At t=2 seconds, the velocity crosses zero and becomes negative.
At t=3 seconds, the velocity reaches -2 m/s.

premise: From t=2 to t=3 seconds, the velocity is negative.
conclusion: The motion is in the negative direction.

premise: The motion is in the negative direction from t=2 to t=3 seconds.
conclusion: The motion direction is opposite to the defined positive direction.
